A worst-case release is unlikely due to the materials of construction of the chlorine container.  In addition, a comprehensive risk management program has been developed to prevent accidental releases.

Alternative Release Scenario

The alternative release scenario modeled is the worst-case scenario with the emergency scrubber in operation It is assumed that a one-ton container reputes and releases all of its contents within the Process/Chemical building.  When the release is detected, the emergency scrubber is activated. There is no off-site impact for the alternative release scenario.  This alternative release scenario is not likely to occur; however, it demonstates that off-site impacts do not occur even for the worst-case scenario when the active mitigation system is used.

Accidental Release Prevention Program

City of Naples is in compliance with 40 CFR 68.  The City has conducted a comprehensive review of the chlorine system as well as administrative, technical, operating and maintenance procedures, in addition to the other required program elements of the regulations.

The City has both passive mitigation, an enclosed building, and active mitigation, an emergency scrubber, to minimize the consequences of an accidental release.  The Risk Management Program addresses actions to minimize the likelihood of an accidental release and to minimize the impact if one occurs.

Five-Year Accident History

The WWTP has not had a significant release of a hazardous substance as defined by 40 CFR 68.

Emergency Response Program

This facility has an emergency response program that is coordinated with the Collier County Comprehensive Emergency Response Plan (ERP) that has been prepared in accordance with all local, state and federal regulations.

Planned Changes to Improve Safety

The hazard review resulted in the development of a list of improvements and an implementation schedule.  This is included in the Risk Management Plan (RMP)

.  Continued training and practices documented in the RMP will continue to improve safety at the facility.  Some of the more significant improvements are listed below:

To Be Completed by August 1999

Due to the chemical nature of chlorine, any work performed in the chlorine area that involves heat or sparks should be closely monitored.   Hot work permitting should be implemented.

Request Standard Operating Procedures and certification that chlorine meets AWWA specifications from the chlorine supplier.  Engineering personnel should review this, as well as the safety requirements in the procurement documents.

Prepare and implement inspection procedures for the lifting beam that is utilized during chlorine container off-loading.

Purchase the proper Chlorine Institute approved wrenches to connect/disconnect chlorine containers.  Implement a replacement plan for damaged wrenches and provide operator training regarding proper wrench use.

The flexible tubing from the chlorine container to the header can potentially become twisted or kinked, resulting in a leak.  Any kinked lines should immediately be replaced.  A preventive maintenance program should be implemented to include annual replacement, or per manufacturer's recommendation.

Scales used to weigh chlorine containers should be calibrated annually, or per manufacturer's recommendation.

The vent line from the pressure relief valve should be inspected, tested, and/or replaced annually.  Replacement should occur annually or per the manufacturer's recommendation. 

Expand on the emergency response plan in this area.  Efforts should be coordinated with Haz Mat.

Define notification and evacuation requirements for plant personnel.  Additional  emergency planning and training are scheduled to occur in January 2000. 

Provide for a cleaning and maintenance program for the emergency dampers per the manufacturer's specifications.  In case of failure, consider a limit switch to notify SCADA.

It is the policy of the City of Naples to operate safe wastewater treatment facilities, reducing to the greatest extent possible any hazards associated with our processes and reducing  any subsequent risk to the surrounding community, employees and the environment.  It is also our policy to work with the surrounding community and local emergency response agencies, and promote a spirit of cooperation and teamwork to provide an effective contingency plan in the unlikely event that a process incident occurs at the facility.

Regulated Substances

The primary activity at the Wastewater Treatment Plant (WWTP) is municipal wastewater treatment.  Chlorine is the only 40 CFR 68 regulated substance at the facility. Chlorine is used primarily as a disinfectant.  The maximum amount of chlorine at the facility is 18 tons.

Worst-Case Release Scenario (WCS)

The Worst-Case release scenario according to EPA's Offsite Consequence Analysis Guidance document is the greatest amount held in a single vessel.  The worst-case scenario is the complete release of chlorine from a one-ton container.  The worst-case scenario may not consider the use of active mitigation such as emergency scrubbers.

The chlorine toxic endpoint defined by 40 CFR Part 68 is 0.0087 mg/l which is equivalent to 3 parts million by volume (ppm).  According to the American Industrial Hygiene Association (AIHA) Emergency Response Planning Guideline (ERPG)-2, this toxic endpoint is specified as the maximum airborne concentration below which it is believed that nearly all individuals could be exposed for up to one hour without experiencing or developing irreversible or other serious health effects or symptoms which could impair an individual's ability to take protective action.

The SLAB computer model was used to simulate the worst-case scenario.  The maximum distance to toxic endpoint is 2.08 miles.  This distance considered the mitigation provided by the building but did not include the use of active mitigation m

nd/or replacement of the caustic solution in the scrubber.  The caustic solution should be replaced every four years, at a minimum. Additionally, a preventive maintenance program should be implemented for the scrubber pump and fan, per the manufacturer's recommendations.

To Be Completed by October 1999

A comprehensive safety training program should be developed for the operators and implemented quarterly.

The diaphragm should be replaced in the pressure relief valve and a spare diaphragm kept on site at all times.

Degradation of PVC piping and tubing in the chlorine system occurs over time and it should be replaced every five to seven years.  An evaluation of the piping should be made and a replacement schedule implemented accordingly. 

In case the rate controller valve fails, manual control of flow through the rotameter is implemented.  A spare rotameter should be kept on site at all times.

A spare screen for the Y strainer should be kept on site for replacement when necessary.

Spare valves for the solution line should be kept on site.  The critical valves should be identified and exercised on a regular basis.

High quality pressure gauges should be purchased for the water and solution lines.

There is a danger that visitors or other untrained individuals may enter the chlorine areas, which is a potential risk.  Proper signage at the entrance point and the chlorine area should be posted indicating a  Restricted Area.  The chlorine facility should be locked at all times, beginning in August 1999. 

 To Be Completed by November 1999
A preventive maintenance (PM) and replacement program for the chlorine system should be prepared and implemented.  The PM program should include the following equipment: 

Manual ball valve on header
Vacuum regulator
Injector check valves
Belt and fan on the ventilation system in the chlorinator room
Tubing and piping
Rate controller valve 

To Be Completed by December 1999

A new security gate should be installed at the entrance

to the facility.  It should be kept closed and drivers should be required to check in upon arrival.  A sign should be posted with check- in instructions for all visitors and vendors.  

Discontinue storing containers outside.

Permanent wheel chocks should be installed for the delivery trucks at the point of delivery.  This will help prevent the truck from potentially rolling into the building.  Also provide markings for proper wheel alignment. 

There is a potential danger that the door to the building could shut while off-loading chlorine containers.  This could lead to dropping a container, causing possible injury to the employee, or otherwise compromising the integrity of the container.  A door securing system should be installed.  Prior to its installation, the operator should be required to secure the door while off-loading.

The vendor should be required to verify during procurement that their containers meet all applicable codes and hydrostatic testing requirements.

The current configuration of flexible tubing from the chlorine container to the header should be modified to eliminate potential kinks or dislodging.  A safety guard around the tubing at the header should be installed.
        
The pressure relief valve will currently release chlorine gas to the atmosphere.  The pressure relief valve should be reconfigured so that the released gas is directed to a containment area with necessary alarms provided to initiate emergency scrubber operations.

Chlorinators should be placed on an annual maintenance, inspection and replacement program  per the manufacturer's recommendation.  All gaskets and washers should be replaced when the glass is cleaned, and spares kept on-site at all times.  Provide training for the maintenance personnel.  

There is currently no alarm system in the chlorinator area.  A sensor should be installed   in case of chlorine release to this area. 

Abandoned valves on the chlorine line should be removed and the line capped. 

Consider

connecting the chlorine sensor to the computer system to read the chlorine concentration level.

To Be Completed by January 2000

Complete an emergency evacuation plan for the city complex and maintenance personnel.  The evacuation plan should include two egress routes and designate a location for staff members to reassemble.  Training should be provided to the plant personnel regarding all appropriate actions to take. 

The fencing around the facility compound should be completed.  

Provide a more visible  ON/OFF indicator for the ventilation blower.

A program should be implemented that provides for personnel who wear respirators and/or SCBAs, which includes purchase of spare parts for the equipment, medical exams, fit testing, and training.  Fit testing and training should occur annually.  

Additional lighting should be provided for the chlorine delivery area. The current lighting is insufficient for night operations.

The pressure relief valve will currently release chlorine gas to the outside.  The pressure relief valve should be reconfigured so that gas releases to the chlorine storage building,  near sensors.

Signage should be reviewed.  Vacuum switches, as well as all system components, including pipes to indicate their contents should be reviewed at this time.

The door closer on the door used while off-loading containers should be inspected and replaced if necessary
